0: The U.S. Postal Service said Thursday that its quarterly loss widened to $3.3 billion amid declining mail volume and mounting costs for future retiree health benefits as it struggles to stave off bankruptcy. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR From October through December 2011, losses were $3 billion more than the same period a year ago, even though that quarter is typically the strongest due to increased holiday shipping. The mail agency said that at this rate, it will run out of money by October. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Postal Service is seeking new leeway from Congress to eliminate Saturday mail delivery, raise stamp prices and reduce health and other labor costs. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Also at stake are roughly 100,000 jobs, part of a postal cost-cutting plan to save up to $6.5 billion a year by closing 252 mail processing centers and up to 3,700 post offices. At the request of Congress, the cash-strapped agency agreed to wait until mid-May to begin closures so lawmakers would have time to stabilize its finances first. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Prospects for immediate congressional action remain uncertain. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Passage of legislation is urgently needed that provides the Postal Service with the speed and flexibility needed to cut costs that are not under our control, including employee health costs," said Postmaster General Patrick Donahoe. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said the post office must cut $20 billion in annual costs by 2015 so it can reach profitability, rather than becoming a "long-term burden to taxpayers." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Overall, the post office had income of $17.7 billion from October through December, the first quarter of its 2012 fiscal year. That was down $200 million from the same period last year. Expenses were $17.5 billion. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In addition, the Postal Service had costs stemming from yearly advance payments of roughly $5.5 billion to a future retiree health-benefit fund. Because the agency is low on cash, Congress agreed to extend the legal deadline for last year's payment until this fall, when this year's payment will also be due. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In its financial statement, the post office spread the total $11.1 billion in costs over 12 months, creating additional quarterly debt of more than $3 billion. Without those annual payments _ not required of other government agencies _ the post office would have posted a profit in most recent years and had a loss of roughly $200 million in the last quarter. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Postal Service also has been rocked by declining mail volume as people and businesses continue switching to the Internet in place of letters and paper bills. The number of items mailed during the last quarter was 43.7 billion pieces, a 6 percent decrease, much of it in first-class mail. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On the positive side, postal shipping services such as express and priority mail had an 8 percent increase in income to $3.2 billion, with package volume in the holiday period nearly double that of FedEx and UPS, according to postal officials. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Separate proposals passed last year by House and Senate committees would scrap or reduce the annual health prepayment requirement, but they differ widely on financial oversight and a reduction to five-day-a-week delivery. The Senate initially planned to take action earlier this month but stalled as some lawmakers pushed for changes that would delay decisions on closings and delivery cuts for two more years. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On Thursday, Donahoe said reducing the size of its postal network was critical to its efforts to reduce costs. Closure of mail-processing centers were still planned to begin after mid-May. He said the mail agency was revising some of its proposals to accommodate the needs of rural communities, which rely more heavily on postal service for the delivery of newspapers, prescription drugs and other services. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR As part of the changes, the mail agency plans cuts to first-class mail that would slow delivery and, for the first time, virtually eliminate the chance for stamped letters to arrive the next day. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We have to make sure we are taking actions that are swift to maintain our liquidity and pay our bills," said chief financial officer Joe Corbett, warning that large losses will continue without changes. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Last year, postal losses totaled $5.1 billion. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In the event of a postal shutdown, private companies such as FedEx and UPS could handle a small portion of the material the post office moves, but they do not go everywhere. No business has shown interest in delivering letters everywhere in the country for a set rate of 45 cents for a first-class letter.
